column5: As I wrote above, when you said EAST, I got excited, thinking that maybe, just maybe, east OTP would get some better transit that could make car usage to shop intown less appealing, and improve transit for folks who routinely have to spend upwards of an hour one-way.  As it is, if I am going to walk almost a mile to the bus stop, wait for the bus to get to the train, wait for the train .... or even drive to Indian Creek, Kensington, or Avondale stations and take the train -- I can just drive intown.  Even knowing I will have to wrestle with parking is less hassle.  I would love to take MARTA more often; I have visited enough places in the world with functioning metros that actually were intended for traffic reduction among all social classes, not just relegated to those who had no other option, that I know how valuable they are.  In England I stayed with a friend at St. Alban's.  Within 3/10 of a mile (my measurement) there was a train station.  That whisked me right into London, and I could walk to the British Library to do my work every day.  I traveled all over San Francisco using BART, and never saw driving as more convenient, even though I had access to a car.  Car usage was about even-Steven with the metro in Portland or Seattle, but the metro was a viable option for almost anything.  But here in the south or southwest -- metro lines were primarily maid and working class lines, and it shows.  (I know the ATL ballooned in the 80s and 90s, so the current metro limits make some sense, and I know those eedjits up in Cobb and down in McDonough fought metro expansion very effectively---which makes current traffic unsustainable and makes me glad I chose to live east. Especially when that section of 85 collapsed a couple of years ago .... All the same, while I am very glad to see expansion, wht about REALLY coming East?  Even better, South east, which is massively underserved?  The rich folks in Kirkwood and intown already have options.)

column5: I think this plan is incredibly outdated and short sighted. If we're planning on the future of transit in the 21st century, why are we betting on tracks? Nobody anticipated the rise of LIT transit or the popularity of bicycles or electric bikes. This is revolutionary. But putting an electrified track with a train through the most popular biking and walking corridor??? What a terrible idea. Please do not do this! Please consider other alternatives.
column6: DO NOT PUT RAIL ON BELTLINE. Put it on Randolph or existing streets. YOU WILL KILL CHILDREN. Already the beltline is too congested. We need another lane for wheels. Not a train on the most popular pedestrian space.

column20: General observation about stations on the BeltLine corridor: The stations are too far apart. The SCE extenion is longer than the existing streetcar -- but has only 5 stations, while the existing service (which, again, is shorter in each direction) has 6 stations in each direction. I'm okay with the on-street station placements -- but the stations in the BeltLine corridor should be more frequent.

column17: Mixed traffic with the streetcar would cause bottlenecks in the system, making it hard to maintain headways and reliable service. It's tough to justify riding a streetcar when it's crawling along at the same speed a private car is.
column19: The streetcar does not have its own right of way downtown, and this makes the service worse. I've seen streetcar delays because cars are parked on the tracks, or it's stuck in traffic, or the train got hit by a car. I would put more trust in this train if it had its own dedicated right of way, it sounds like we can do this by closing car traffic on Edgewood or Irwin street.

column3: Great idea to build the wye at Irwin Street for future expansion. Recommend typical railroad gate arms for controlling crossing. Raised bike lanes along Irwin St for the portion along the streetcar alignment. Wayfinding signs from station to local businesses.
column4: This is a great proposal! This is the ideal proposal for this corridor. It extends the feel of the BeltLine where pedestrians, cyclists, and other LIT users feel comfortable away from high speed vehicles. This proposal will boost the businesses along Edgewood Ave with customers traveling between Downtown and BeltLine in a multimodal cooridor.
column5: The Edgewood Ave Cycle Track idea would extend the experience of the BeltLine, where people can safely walk, roll without worrying about high speed vehicles. This extends that experience to the businesses along Edgewoood Ave. Bringing more customers. This builds on Councilmember Farokhi plan to close Edgewood Ave to vehicles at certain times: https://t.co/LS1RERuTP8?amp=1. The Streetcar and car-free Edgewood Ave will attract enough customers to offset any who would not visit because access to free and easy parking.

column3: Micromobility users will not be able to safely traverse the tracks in this configuration.
column5:
I noticed several presenters repeated a variation of the phrase, “Well, transit has ALWAYS been part of Beltline plan from the beginning,” almost as a mantra. This makes the planning process appear hidebound and unable to adapt to current or future conditions. When Ryan Gravel wrote his thesis over 20 years ago, micromobility was not a word that was in use. E-scooters did not exist. E-bikes were almost unknown.
Imagine if someone in 1921 pushed a transportation scheme that was dreamed up in 1899. Would it still be useful? Of course not. Now that the micromobility revolution is upon us, we are now in that same scenario. MARTA needs to adapt to this reality before people start asking why time and resources are being allocated in pursuit of obsolete, expensive plans.
column6: The streetcar stops cannot be located where they harm the capacity and flow of foot and micromobility traffic on the Beltline.

column3: My primary concern here is conflicts between cars and the streetcar. I'd recommend blocking vehicular access to Irwin Street between the intersections with Sampson Street and Krog Street.
column4: My comments on this section largely mirror those made for question 6E.
column5: I urge you to reconsider the lack of dedicated lanes on Edgewood Ave and the retaining of on-street parking. We've had the streetcar for over six years, and we know what works and what doesn't. I would much rather see bus rapid transit projects prioritized over this if MARTA is planning on repeating failures. The current streetcar is counterintuitively closed on days when the city experiences high traffic for an event. This demonstrates that not even MARTA views it as transportation. If you want people to ride, you have to prioritize them instead of everyone else. The BeltLine sections are designed well, but on-street sections are setting up this entire line for low ridership and disappointment.

column3: Add more pedestrian crossings wherever possible. Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less storm water runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every Beltline rendering ever created. Improve connectivity for cyclists and pedestrians at stations by installing amenities like secure bicycle lockers and Beltline-branded shelters and benches.  I understand MARTA's need for safety and security protection and I see that the material is TBD. I recommend working closely with ABI on the design of the railbed (always intended to be a greenway), pedestrian crossings and on the design of the safety and security barriers. If possible these should be visually permeable as is the fencing on the BeltLine trails, stairs, etc. Function is important, but so is aesthetics. One of the reasons the BeltLine is so popular is the aesthetics.
column4: Add more pedestrian crossings wherever possible. One of the reasons the BeltLine is so popular is the aesthetics.
column5:
Accelerate the timeline for this project.
Voters, including me, passed the increased sales tax in 2016. Collections began in April 2017, but this project is not scheduled to be complete until 2027. That's way too long! It should be expedited and reduced by 2 or 3 years. I've heard this project referred to as a "proof of concept" for LRT on the BeltLine. To really be useful as a proof of concept the concept should be presented to the public as soon as possible.    
Fix the Existing Streetcar
    Reduce transit times by getting the streetcar out of traffic.
    Support lane closures to vehicles both on the original route and the extension where practical.
    Increased frequency of service (every 10 minutes instead of every 15).
    Install a new station at the corner of Luckie Street and Forsyth Street to connect Peachtree Center MARTA to eastbound riders.
    Give the streetcar the right of way by installing priority signaling across the entire route (both existing and new). 
Question two of this survey is not functional. It will only allow me to inset a "Play" icon in one place. Play includes shopping, recreation and entertainment. I could have added this icon in at least a dozen locations.
column6: Move stops closer to cross-streets (like Highland and Ralph McGill) so that it is easier for pedestrians and cyclists to connect.

column2: I also support existing closure of existing streets on the existing streetcar route provide dedicated right of way for the streetcar along the entirety of its route! Close Edgewood Abe completely to personally owned/operated vehicles all day every day, 24/7/365.
column3: With the rail spur traveled down to DeKalb Ave.
column4: Absolutely love the cycle track and protection. Close down all of Edgewood Ave so no personally owned vehicles access the street. Only allow transit, bikes, pedestrians, and emergency vehicles!
column5:
All the barriers for light rail on the BeltLine need to be easily navigable for able bodied people to hop open. They’re going to run along the tracks whether you or the FTA want to admit that or not.

Turn Edgewood Ave into a closed street to only transit, bike, and pedestrians.

Existing streetcar route, as in what’s already built needs to be provided dedicated right of way and no longer run in shared lanes. Transit signal priority only does so much. Get the dedicated right of way and stop making excuses. Other cities complete several mile streetcar extensions in the same timeline you’re looking to add 2.5 miles. The least you can do is guarantee dedicated right of way so we don’t have to sit in traffic when we ride the route.
column6: At current & future transit connections, including bus routes! Encourage timely transfers!

column5: Consideration needs to be given to cycling facilities leaving Downtown going east. Taking out the Edgewood bike lane for the street car took out the only separated cycling facility, and it was not replaced. Putting sharrows on Auburn was not a solution, as traffic is often backed up in the evenings from Piedmont back to Woodruff Park, and cyclists are stuck in it too. By the time the bike lane starts at Jesse Hill, most cars have turned off at Piedmont, Courtland, or Bell street, and there isn't even that much traffic anymore.

column20: Have you considered using BRT with dedicated lanes (in street) instead of light rail? The cost vs benefits to this project don't make sense to me. The obstacles are massive and the construction will infuriate most of your stakeholders. There is no way you can build this in three years. The area will be considerable more congested before you start construction. I think the entire project is ill-conceived. It sounds good on paper but you are opening a Pandora's Box here. Forget transit on the Beltline. Focus on getting people around town. It's already 30 years too late. ATL is going to be on giant gridlock in five years.

column3: I'm sure y'all know this but this intersection is an absolute zoo. It's horrible for cyclist and drivers alike, and barley passable for pedestrians. Adding a streetcar in the current state is impossible in my opinion. The road either needs to be closed to cars here or some really intricate signaling needs to be installed and programmed.
column4:
This is beautiful and makes me cry tears of joy.
I worry that if the sidewalk here is super busy than people will be standing in the bike lane, so maybe install a barrier/planters to keep it separated. Also try to make the turn at Jackson street less 90 degree and smoother. Maybe a diagonal crossing like is already at a lot of lights on the Beltline.
column5:
- Why does the streetcar only go up to 25 mph even though it will have it's own RoW on the trail sections? Factoring in stops and waiting time I feel like that speed is more comparable to biking than a true modal alternative.
- Please push to get as much dedicated RoW for the street car. You and I both know that enforcement for parking in the street and other stuff will be poor/lax as it always is, so the only way to ensure the path is clear is to get the cars out of the way. Literally every other road in this city caters to cars, bikes, transit, and the vibrant businesses on Edgewood deserve a true street for people.
- Reconsider not choosing alignment alternative 2. It's better for everyone that will ride the streetcar one day, and only worse for a few people against progress. Doesn't seem fair to select a longer route, inconveniencing everyone, at the benefit of a very few.
- The "Home |  Work |  Meet |  Play" map doesn't work for me
column6: Major Access Points and/or cross streets, like how bus stops are typically at the intersection of two roads.

- That construction will run overtime and overbudget by a lot, as public infrastructure (but rarely private projects) tend to do.

column5: I am very interested in designating some major thoroughfares in Atlanta, like Edgewood, for ped /bike /streetcar use only.  I have lived and bike commuted in Atlanta for 15+ years and while it is always improving, and is leaps and bounds from what bike infrastructure was in 2005--I have yet to go a week without someone yelling at me to get off the road.  I think Atlanta should lead the way for alternative transportation.

column3: This placement concerns me as it seems like a "far" walk from the main intersection at Irwin.  I'd like to see this station placed just north of Irwin so it's visible from Krog St. Market, Irwin St and the Beltline - I think this would greatly enhance the existing node and get a lot more passersby interested in taking the streetcar.
column4: Yes yes YES YES and YES! THIS MUST BE DONE - especially if it comes with widened sidewalks on Edgewood
column5:
1) I really really hope there's more conversation around the track couplet taking riders west on Auburn/east on Edgewood.  This would take so much pressure off of Edgewood and limit the inevitable bottlenecks that 2-way streetcar traffic would cause on the ALREADY congested street.  I feel as if having one-way streetcar on both Edgewood and Auburn would at least give MARTA the option to possibly bypass Edgewood on extremely busy nights when the streetcar would surely get stuck.  If it has to be 2-way on Edgewood, we HAVE to have options where Edgewood is closed to through vehicular traffic.  

2) I think there needs to be another stop around the Edgewood & Randolph intersection.  The distance from the Boulevard stop to the Irwin stop is already about twice as long as most of the other stop distances.  Adding a stop at the Randolph turn would make the streetcar even more attractive option for all the development on the Beltline at Edgewood so that they wouldn't be caught between 2 stations that are pretty far to walk to comfortably.

column3: This is a tricky section, and I can't think of a better way than what is proposed. It is what it is. Perhaps new signals for this one block portion that will give the streetcar priority so it can easily make these tight turns without getting stuck behind cars or having to wait for pedestrians and bikes.
column4:
This is amazing, and would essentially serve as an extension of the Beltline that allows for safe transportation by train, bike, and foot. To improve safety and improve timeliness of the streetcar, all motor vehicle traffic from this section of Edgewood should be removed. There are plenty of parallel routes available for cars ( Auburn, Irwin, John Wesley Dobbs, Decatur St, Memorial, Freedom Parkway, etc). Removing the "mixed traffic" component of this section would create an attractive and safe "transportation mall" allowing quick transit times and full access of all businesses on Edgewood.
The cycle track here must be high quality in order to be successful. It must be wide, smoothly paved, well marked, and adequately blocked to prevent cars from parking or idling in it. It should also be accompanied by new bike racks along Edgewood Street.
column5: What is the best way to avoid a car (motor vehicle) breaking down or parking and blocking the streetcar tracks on Edgewood?

column4: I like the dedicated lane here, but you have to police cars and vans from not parking in the bike lanes as they do in other parts of the city (downtown) for deliveries and even cabs. column20: This stop makes sense, though at the skate park you might need fencing or netting to keep Frisbees, footballs, soccer balls, etc. from getting onto the tracks, especially if since you're adding a barrier.
column21: Certainly, on Edgewood you have to give the streetcar priority in order to make it successful and not sitting in traffic. column3: Let's close Auburn (between Randolph and Irwin) and this short stretch of Irwin to car traffic, please. There are plenty of parallel alternates in this area. Priority should be given to streetcar, pedestrian and LIT.
column4: Same comments as above - streetcar should be separated from traffic (own right-of-way.) column15: None here - damage was already done when the wonderful ramp was taken away for the new elevator.
column17: I appreciate having an additional cycle track on Auburn, because right now the Edgewood bike lane only works east of Boulevard. West of Boulevard it's a disaster and I just take the lane. Also, honestly, Edgewood should really be closed to car traffic or at least given dedicated right-of-way for the entire distance it runs on-street. (It's not difficult - the venerable St. Charles Streetcar in New Orleans runs in the median for most of its length.) I am OK if all car traffic is removed from streetcar routes, but there may be room for one-way traffic on some of these stretches.
column18: Concerned that the east side of the platform takes up existing paved Beltline right-of-way. Would love to widen the multiuse path to make up for this.
column19: I am concerned that the streecar's current failings (primarily running in traffic vs. having its own right-of-way/priority) will be extended to the trail, also that the area it currently DOES run in traffic will be a bottleneck for the entire system. Also concerned about the pedestrian/cyclist experience but that's a runner up. Gotta get the transit part right if you're going to build it. Finally, I'm a car owner and live right next to I-20, but please close every street to traffic and remove all the on-street parking if it will make the transit work better.
column20: Would want to ensure good pedestrian access from streetcar/Beltline to N. Highland. Right now people tend to go through the parking lots on the east side. Would love a stairway/ramp up to the overpass or some designated path for ped flow.

column3:
- Overall looks good given this is a tricky intersection.  
- I would support this section being closed to vehicular traffic  
- Will the Sampson/Irwin intersection remain a stop sign, or will a traffic signal or other traffic management be implemented?  A stop sign seems like it would be problematic.
column4:
I prefer this alignment to the couplet plan, and I support this section of the route to be closed to vehicular traffic.  One concern:
- If this section remains open to vehicular traffic, is there a plan in place to limit curb cuts along the route?  With no dedicated turn lanes, I worry traffic may be backed up by turning vehicles
column5:
I would love to see most of the route in dedicated lanes, especially the existing Downtown section.  The most practical solution seems to be converting Edgewood and Auburn to 1-way streets and allocating the full lane to the streetcar.  

Also, I want to emphasize my support for the closure of Edgewood along the streetcar route and the Irwin/Beltline intersection to vehicular traffic.

column2: I might support some full closures for pedestrian/bike movements, but not for transit.
column3: I oppose placing transit in the BeltLine corridor. The Eastside BeltLine is already overcrowded with pedestrians and bikes/scooters/skateboards. Any excess space should be used to build out dedicated lanes for bikes/scooters/skateboards. The demand for this is evident now. The demand for mass transit along the BeltLine corridor is speculative.
column5: I oppose placing transit in the BeltLine corridor. The Eastside BeltLine is already overcrowded with pedestrians and bikes/scooters/skateboards. Any excess space should be used to build out dedicated lanes for bikes/scooters/skateboards. The demand for this is evident now. The demand for mass transit along the BeltLine corridor is speculative.  I am especially concerned about the BeltLine space adjacent to Ponce City Market that is already fully occupied by pedestrian/bike/scooter traffic.  I would support terminating the streetcar at the proposed Auburn at Irwin stop that is near the BeltLine but not on it.
column6: Near, but not on the BeltLine.  I do not support transit on the BeltLine corridor.  There is too much demand there for pedestrian/bike/scooter traffic already.

column5: This project needs to be done right, and half measures will lead to another failure/boondoggle of a project like the current streetcar. Pedestrians, transit riders and cyclists are rarely prioritized in ATL, and having an example of what that looks like can be a great starting point for getting buy-in for other projects around the city. Atlanta already has a glut of car parking, as well as alternate surface streets if Edgewood is closed to cars. You will get pushback either way, but if you succumb to it, this project will be doomed from the start.

column5:
Clarification to question 11: There presently *no* "protected bike lanes" on either Edgewood nor Auburn. So, if by "continuation" of these is meant a full build-out of actual, permanent protected lanes, then I'm all for B in question 11*.
If it's just more road paint, again . . . well, you can put that paint where the sun don't shine.

* The terms used -- "protected" "buffered" etc. -- carry specific meaning. That the survey writer did not seem know this speaks to the seriousness taken regarding transport by bicycle . . . minimal.

column1: ['other']
column2: For the streetcar to be an effective mode of transit along the existing route or along the extension partial or full street closures should be considered throughout to prevent other vehicular traffic from blocking the streetcar and affecting its performance and headway.  The right of way should be prioritized for pedestrians, cyclists, e-scooter riders, wheelchair users, then rapid bus transit and light rail transit aka the streetcar. I don't ride it currently because it is faster to walk, ride my bike, or use rideshare because it is also stuck behind other vehicles.
column3: Will the alternate bike route be protected?  It should be and I also wonder how those protective barriers will meet the streetcar track as it turn between Irwin & Auburn Ave.
column4:
This is preferable IF street closures do happen but it must still have appropriate separation from both ped and vehicular traffic and not just flex posts and wheelstops. If it is a solid barrier as can be found along Bill Kennedy Way then cars could still fit into it unless there are solid bollards keeping cars out.

Another option is from Hilliard to Boulevard is that it could just be a ped plaza that keeps cars out and no designated bike lanes are given as cyclists and pedestrians will have the entire space to use unless a street car is coming and needs the space.  Pedestrians move and don't block on-coming traffic that could hurt them like cars do.
column5: If full closure occurs along Edgewood Avenue then I would prefer either a protected cycle track along it or separated bike lanes on Edgewood that also have some sort of protected separation from pedestrians and of course from vehicular traffic on blocks east of Boulevard.
column6: Major intersections that have a combinations of all the above should be prioritized.  Where the streetcar line ends and where it crosses Ralph McGill, Freedom Parkway, Irwin Street, Randolph, and Boulevard stand out the most to me.

column11: The stop should be along the Eastside Trail of the Atlanta BeltLine just north of Irwin vs. along Auburn Avenue. Most riders in the area are going to or leaving from businesses along the BeltLine so why inconvenience them by putting the stop away from this the corridor along Auburn Avenue?  In the future when the streetcar goes south it is better also to have the stop along BeltLine so that when a streetcar goes south it won't need to shift over to drop people off along the stop if it was on Auburn Avenue.

column4: I oppose cycle tracks that take public property for the benefit of cyclists: a small, wealthy, privileged, and vocal group, to the detriment of the rest of society.
column5: Separating cyclists from cars on city streets has minimal value - the city has a connected street grid in this area, with many good, low traffic options for cyclists (including myself - I regularly commute by bike).  The real issue for bike separation is on the beltline itself, where a separate cycleways would protect pedestrians from bicycles, which cannot intermingle safely in the limited space available.

column21: I urge you to consider traffic flow in and out of Inman Park. Even with the streetcar extension, traffic will be even more choked at Irwin. It’s hard enough to get to the highway already, with Irwin/Beltline, Dekalb/Krog, Edgewood/Boulevard intersections all being choke points, and now you’re putting rail through two of those. Don’t kid yourselves, this extension isn’t going to take any cars off the road, so if you start closing streets, how will those cars go east/west? It’ll force all cars onto Highland which is unsafe enough already.

column1: ['Loss of on-street parking', 'other']
column3: This section DOES NOT need to be closed to vehicles. Adding signals that control the entire intersection between the beltline and Sampson with proper synchronization are all that are required. Closing this segment would remove a critical E-W traffic route and just add traffic to Edgewood (which would in-turn negatively impact the streetcar), and North Highland Ave.
column5:
I would strongly suggest exploring a ground-level power supply option instead of catenary. A number of examples of these are in use in Europe and dramatically cut down on visual pollution and thus neighborhood opposition as well as increase safety since there is no continuously energized high voltage line anywhere except maybe shop areas.

I would also strongly explore making Edgewood and Auburn one way in the existing streetcar area which would improve reliability on the new segment. Then the streetcar could have a dedicated lane and be caught in traffic much less than now.

column2: The entire streetcar right of way should have no impediments from car traffic/parking, otherwise it will not play well with the BeltLine section of the line. The only vehicular traffic allowed should be police and delivery trucks (not food delivery drivers).
column3: It is nice that that drawing shows the switch and tracks into the southern portion of the BeltLine, so line can be reconfured in the future. The turn radius into the BeltLine looks very tight and cause wheels to make the screeching sound. Is there a way to have the alignment less curvy there? Can the entire section on Irwin Street between Auburn Ave and the BeltLine be turned into a pedestrian-dominant plaza that lets cars through at a very slow speed?
column4: Yay to this! With the current proposal, all car traffic and parking on Edgewood should be removed except for truck deliveries (car access to intersecting streets can be done from DeKalb Ave or Auburn Ave).
column5: I really want to reemphasize, a 10-minute frequency should be the goal, we are talking about a rail line in the city core serving a large public that in the past would not generally use MARTA and has competing means to travel faster (rental scooters, ride-hail) if wait times are excessive. Looking forward to updates! Thank you.

column1: ['Impact to pedestrian/cyclist experience on the BeltLine trail', 'Loss of trees/tree canopy', 'other']
column3: I don't support the streetcar along the beltline above ground. An above ground street car along the beltline would harm the beltline experience and make it harder for beltline users to access neighboring businesses. I think the city should build infill Marta stations, particularly at the Krog Street Tunnel on the Blue/Green lines, to connect to the beltline at strategic points. The city should focus on expanding heavy rail, underground Marta service instead of slow and streetcars that obstruct pedestrian uses above ground. Underground marta service would be faster and would be better connected to the existing Marta rail lines.

column2: Only close Irwin from Sampson to Krog IF streetcar (double track) is routed dowN Irwin and not Auburn (at water tower). Irwin is an important west-East connection in an area where that acces is limited, particularly with Boulevard’s lack of turn lanes toward East
column3:
Agree with the routing. Work closely with Asana on locating stop for easy direct off-street access to Krog Street Market etc
Irwin/BeltLine intersection is already confusing as a pedestrian, car, or biker—this will further complicate. Extensive study on how to let all flow together is needed—this plan isn’t quite there yet  (streetcar will get stuck in traffic, badly, as designed)
column4: Map is confusing with missing and misplaced street names. Assuming Eastbound stop is to East of the sheer cutoff? I like the 2-way cycle track on Edgewood IF we can block delivery trucks/Uber/etc from parking in the lane. Physical barrier needed here.
column5: Thank you for the outreach and taking input! This was challenging to answer on a mobile device, which you should assume most people are using. Please share this survey broadly, including on prominent physical signs with QR code’s along route. Thank you again!

column15: Love the connection to Ralph McGill. Assume you’re working closely with New City to align streetcar stop optimally with key access point; if not please make that a priority. Would be GREAT if a non-stairs/non-elevator connection can be made from this stop to Old Fourth Ward Park.
column17: Are you placing eastbound bike traffic on Auburn Ave? I ride my bike down Edgewood as part of commute; open to shifting to Auburn but it doesn’t make a lot of sense. This appears to need more study for people to feel properly oriented (esp infrequent travelers and visitors)—VERY clear signage and painting needed too.
column18: Additional cross connections needed at Ponce City Market to Kroger (at central opening in 725 Ponce), Ponce, and North. Direct BeltLine connection needed from Ponce.
column19: Conflicts between vehicular traffic and the Streetcar where it’s not in dedicated lanes; lack of connectivity to existing MARTA heavy rail stations (Inman?)
column20:
Overall good. Better if you can build ped/bike access from Freedom Parkway streetlevel to BeltLine (currently grade separated) to more easily draw neighbors from Poncey Highland etc to this stop. Possible connection at Carter Center underpass.
Proposed Station Location is good.
column21: And perhaps other places evenings and events. The targeted street closures could negatively impact local businesses if during business hours, and we should be particularly wary of locating them in exclusively underresourced areas. Try the street closures in Inman Park first. Conflicted about Irwin.

column3: I am worried about vehicles causing major delays in the streetcar. This would likely be the biggest conflict point for cars, transit, bikes, and pedestrians on the whole route. Maybe this section of Irwin should be closed to vehicles.
column4: I am very supportive of a cycle track here so long as it is at least as wide as the 10th street cycle track and provides actual protection from vehicles. I also would love to see floating stations.
column5:
1. Trust. The biggest reason I never use the streetcar today despite living within a 10 minute walk is the embarrassing headways and inconsistency. Why would anyone use transit they can't trust? Will MARTA extend streetcar hours to match heavy rail? Will the streetcar continue to suspend service during major events? Will the streetcar continue to get delayed by personal vehicles?
2. We need dedicated ROW or, at a minimum, signal priority. And not just the kind that holds a green light or shortens a red light, I want it to turn green for the streetcar automatically.
3. Edgewood should be closed to personal vehicles. Otherwise the streetcar will be unable to maintain a schedule.
4. The streetcar needs to run as late as MARTA heavy rail and weekend service should mirror weekday.
5. I like the current number of stations. Any more would slow things down too much.
6. I would prefer to see the base of the track on the beltline to be grass.

column5: Please show Atlanta citizens what objective data you have that this extension would be used enough to justify the cost.  The current line is a complete waste on money and has been each and every day of existence.  Marta needs to prove that this is not just another of its efforts to move people from where they are not to here they do not want to be.  I chair NPU-A, and our members are getting really tired of our tax dollars being wasted on useless projects.

column17: Stop worrying about on street parking, or putting a streetcar on a predominantly residential street. This city needs to stop catering to cars entirely. There’s no reason why we should be having a discussion about bringing public transportation up to standards set by the early twentieth century, we’re in the twenty-first century. Look at old maps of how expansive this city’s streetcar system used to be. There’s no reason why in a city this large, people have to have a car.

column1: ['other']
column5:
Possibly out of scope, but I'd love to see a cycle track ::ON:: the beltline itself! There is certainly demand for it and this would significantly enhance bike commuter mobility. Regarding the bike facilities in Question 11, I have two thoughts: 
1. It seems to me to be best to continue and expand upon the existing network, or at least keep future continuation in mind. Protected, two-way cycle tracks are great, but if it's just a brief segment, and cyclists are forced back into the conventional bike lanes or into shared car lanes after a 1/2 mile, this creates extra conflict points at intersections, and it seems to make more sense to continue the conventional bike lanes. 
2. Thought needs to be put into the larger network! Atlanta typically installs bike infrastructure in tiny segments that don't connect. An ideal network would link destinations to existing infrastructure, i.e. the beltline and FP trail.
Thanks for reading!!! Looking forward to your plans!!

column5: So excited about the possibility of additional streetcars.  We need more than this, but it is a good place to start. I couldn't get the question 1 and 2 maps to function properly, so wanted to comment here too.  I do not live in the exact area, but do work and play in it.  I ride my bike all of the time, and it would be amazing to have bike paths and street cars in the area to really help ease traffic and give people an alternate way to get around.  It is going to be essential for our city to have better transportation as we continue to grow.  I think this is just the start and if people can see it being successful on the beltline it can succeed other places.
column6: I am not sure if number of residents or jobs are more important so ranked them the same.  I love this as a start, but would love to see this on the entire beltline, particularly areas that are not as redeveloped already since the street car will serve as a more needed form of transportation.  But support all efforts for the street car since we have to start somewhere.  Love that this is finally being put for for public comment, and I strongly support effort.

column1: ['Loss of on-street parking', 'Impacts to current property values', 'Impact to pedestrian/cyclist experience on the BeltLine trail', 'other']
column2: I think traffic calming measures should be used in place of completely closing roads to vehicular traffic, as well as expanding space for bike lanes and pedestrian spaces (particularly along Irwin St).Perhaps limiting on-street parking (or making it closer to the main roadway to slow drivers), narrowing the main roadway, and using that extra space to create dedicated bike lanes as well as expanding the sidewalks (as 2 separate entities, in order to separate bicyclists from pedestrians). Also, lower the speed limit on that section of Irwin St from 30 to 25 mph, as well as create raised pedestrian crossings similar to how the Beltline currently crosses the street.
column3: Please re-route. The stretch of Irwin St between Auburn Ave and Krog St at the Beltline crossing is one of the most congested, if not the most congested segment of Irwin St, especially on the Weekends or Holidays. Perhaps run the Streetcar on Krog St instead and cross at the 4-way stop with Irwin St/Lake Ave (and include a stop at Krog St Market?), or perhaps run the Streetcar down Randolph St and use John Wesley Dobbs Ave or McGruder St to then cut over to the Beltline. In that scenario, could also include a stop at/near Ladybird Mess Hall.
column4: Same concerns as my answer to 6E.
column5: Try to convince the mayor's office to enact rent control in the area, as to fight increased gentrification and prevent lower-income residents being forced to move out of the area.
column8: {'Near places with the highest number of jobs': '3', 'Near places with the greatest potential for redevelopment': '5', 'Near places with the highest number of residents (apartments, condominiums)': '1', 'Near places with the highest number of destinations (shopping, restaurants, services)': '2', 'Near places with a high number of community facilities (parks, churches, recreational)': '4'}
column9: The Beltline and Streetcars need to be completely separated with no at-grade crossings as not to disrupt traffic on either route.
column11: Same concerns as my answer to 6G. Plus, the reduction of on-street parking on Auburn Ave will instead cause those people to park elsewhere (on perhaps a busier road) instead of the relatively less-busy Auburn Ave. If there is any road to eliminate on-street parking on, it should be Irwin St between Krog St and Randolph St. Perhaps run a bike lane down Auburn Ave instead to connect with the Beltline?
column13: ['I do not support partial closures of existing streets to vehicular traffic', 'other']
column14: ['Edgewood Avenue, between Jackson Street and Boulevard SE', 'Edgewood Avenue, between Hillard Street SE and Jackson Street']
column15: This stop is in a great location with easy access to the residences along the beltline, but again, ensure that the Beltline and Streetcars are completely grade-separated as to not disrupt traffic and safety on either.
column17: Try to limit traffic on both Edgewood Ave (esp. Edgewood Ave) and Boulevard as to try to prevent the Streetcar from getting stuck in or blocked by traffic. Also put in protected crossings for the bike lanes crossing Boulevard on both Edgewood and Auburn, as that stretch of Boulevard is incredibly busy and could cause a cyclist to feel unsafe crossing. Also limit/eliminate left-hand turns off Edgewood/Auburn as to increase traffic flow.
column18: The Beltline and Streetcars need to be completely separated with no at-grade crossings as not to disrupt traffic on either route. The stop is in a good location though, with easy access to both Ponce City Market as well as the 725 Ponce Kroger.
column19: Long-term increased vehicle traffic around the already somewhat congested Old Fourth Ward/Streetcar East Extension area.
column20: The Beltline and Streetcars need to be completely separated with no at-grade crossings as not to disrupt traffic on either route. The Highland-Freedom stop is in a good location, though.

This can unite our city, enabling residents/visitors/tourist more accessible ways to explore our city.  If this is done right, Atlanta has a chance of developing a transit system that works with its rapid expansion.

column3: Close this street down entirely to car traffic and have the tram stop where it curves in the picture - this will be an open gathering space.
column5:
People should be able to access the streetcar by using their MARTA cards. If someone chooses to get off of the MARTA and get on the streetcar, then they shouldn't be charged anything extra as long as it is within the three connections limit.

Stations should be filled with art by local artists. Make stations unique with fun names (maybe even get the public's input on names). Make stations colorful - this will cause people to want to take pictures by each station, which would create a better image for the City of Atlanta and allow for more usage of the streetcar. Stations should be lit well as well.

For the border protection of where the streetcar drives, please place MANY trees/shrubs! Let's make this as green of a project as possible! Create a natural barrier rather than an artificial one.

The beltline does not have enough trash and recycle receptacles. Each station should have several. Each streetcar should have two trash bins within it by opposing doors. Inform the streetcar operators to enforce no eating or drinking on the streetcars if possible. Have streetcar operators clean the streetcars after one full run. Place one main trash receptacle by the start/Ponce de Leon station for use only by the streetcar operators (give them access with a key/lock).
column6: Absolutely one stop should be next to the MARTA train line

column3: Auburn Ave and Irwin is not a good connector to the Beltline - the expansion should go down Dekalb Ave and connect King Memorial Transit Center. The connection should occur at Dekalb Ave near Krog Street Market. The rail line needs to be expanded more, not concentrated through a historic neighborhood.
column5: It is important to reimagine the current streetcar line. It must connect to a Marta station - period. King Memorial is the best connection station - the line can travel from downtown, eastward on Dekalb Ave and turn onto the Beltline near Krog Street. It is the best and most viable option that would increase functionality and ridership.

column4: MARTA and City of Atlanta do not maintain the streetcar route. It is full of trash and lingering people. It has lowered the quality of character of Edgewood Avenue and I assume it will do the same as it starts going through the residential areas. I do not think the streetcar rail system will be well received as it moves through Atlanta neighborhoods. We should be looking at EVs, driverless shuttles, and other lower cost and lower impact transit that would position Atlanta as a leader in technology, not an antiquated system that no one rides or wants in their backyard and will be invasive and deteriorating to quality of life..
column5: MARTA should be considering putting the street car down Irwin instead. It is less invasive to the local historic district, single family neighborhood, and would have larger public right of way to work with. We should also be considering and prioritizing more modern technology versus implementing an antiquated streetcar model. Traffic calming and streetscaping should be implemented on surrounding residential streets that will very likely experience negative impacts by the streetcar route.

G: Bike tire and rails don't mix well. I would pref protected bike lanes (both directions) on Auburn, streetcar (both directions) Edgewood.

A line along the Beltline that connects to existing MARTA lines would be the easiest way with least community impact to get rail on the Beltline, as originally imagined.

column1: ['Impact to pedestrian/cyclist experience on the BeltLine trail', 'other']
column2: All existing streetcar lanes.
column3: Maybe the section between Auburn and the BeltLine should become one big signalized intersection, with crossing arms for trains, that stops traffic from entering, and allows trains to slip right through. Something would probably need to be done to keep trail users from blocking the intersection, and letting backed up traffic get out.
column4:
I understand the concerns about impacting historic sites, but would it maybe make more sense to put both streetcar tracks onto Auburn, and make that whole stretch from Jackson all the way to the BeltLine basically a transit mall, with pedestrians allowed to walk around as well?

That way Edgewood remains as the major E-W connection, including with bike facilities, without mixing traffic?
column5: It isn't really said explicitly anywhere, but please make the tracks themselves grass-covered rails. Greenway transit is nice, and would work well with the BeltLine. I also don't know how serious you need to get with barriers. The size you need to have to really stop people from crossing would basically hem in the BeltLine in a way that utterly destroys the linear park nature of it as well. It's a case where a low barrier, enough to make the point of demarcating space, is enough to stop people without limiting the openness of the space. Better, also, to give people an easy way out of the light rail right of way rather than box them in as well.
column6: Connections to other major transit routes (high frequency / high capacity routes)

column9:
Parking lots around here should definitely be filled in with development.

There should also be some kind of proper access down into the shops at the end of Krog, rather than walking through the grass.

Also, maybe a new access point to the Highland Walk Apartments' drive-around? Closer to the end of Krog. Between the radio tower and dog park perhaps?
column11: Please just make Auburn a transit mall.
column13: ['Irwin Street, between Sampson Street and Krog Street', 'Edgewood Avenue, between Jackson Street and Boulevard SE', 'Edgewood Avenue, between Hillard Street SE and Jackson Street', 'other']
column14: ['Irwin Street, between Sampson Street and Krog Street', 'Edgewood Avenue, between Jackson Street and Boulevard SE', 'Edgewood Avenue, between Hillard Street SE and Jackson Street', 'other']
column15: A proper bus stop, shelter, bulb out, information sign, etc. needs to be built on Ralph McGill if buses are going to continue to use it. Also, upping the frequency of the 816 would be great, as a feeder compliment for the light rail.
column17:
It really feels like there needs to be dedicated transit lanes. This area is such a cluster mess of car traffic even at the best of times.

Usually I don't like adding lanes, but this might be one of the few places that widening Boulevard to a consistent 4 lanes south of Edgewood to the DeKalb Ave access split makes sense, just to remove the odd southbound turn lane there at Edgewood.

Is there any way the Bike Couplets on the whole length could get some protection? A curb? Some bollards? Something?
column18:
This is a VERY active spot. The traffic over the North Ave bridge is already quite significant as is. Since it'll be the end of the line for a while, perhaps it'd be best to make the tracks something of a shared space?

Cutting down the trail to just one part may cause issues. Is the full bridge width really needed for two tracks?

Also, there were plans at some point for vertical access to Ponce on the west side of the trail. I assume that's been considered in the plans?

I really wish the North Ave route was going to be light rail. Seems like y'all should be able to scrape together some funds from business partners along the route to close out funding gaps for that.
column19: Maintaining transit priority such that trains don't get stuck in traffic.
column20:
Has any effort been put into discussing the possibility of retrofitting some of the ground-level units of the Steel Apartments into trail & transit facing shops?

Also, either some better way finding needs to be installed, or else another vertical access method should be built so people can access North Highland from the west side of the trail, and not need to go the long way around.

It would be nice if there was an actual bus route that used this part of North Highland, as the bridge's parking spaces would make for decent station space.
column21: All existing streetcar lanes.

column3: I favor all plans that prioritize bikers and pedestrian safety - that must be a core concern! I am rail agnostic - I hope there is a way to put light rail in safely, and in a way that removes the dominance of cars on our streets. Yes to all proposals to permanent road closures to make way for our vision of multi-model, low-carbon, equitable transit.
column4: I favor all plans that prioritize bikers and pedestrian safety - that must be a core concern! column5: Please prioritize truly protected bike lanes at all turns of this process. And by protection, I do not feel flexible plastic bollards, but hard infrastructure like concrete curbs, pile-ons, planters, etc. That remains my top priority as a daily bike commuter who has 4 kids biking to Grady cluster schools every day. The Irwin Randolph area must consider school access for walkers and bikers to Howard, which is currently marginal and hopefully could be improved by future strategic planning around this expansion project.
column6: let's take advantage of public transit to allow teachers and students to get to and from schools and colleges safely - these are permanent structures serving a diverse constituency, and would save thousands of daily car trips per year! Let's think carbon benefits too.

column3: Dangerous for foot traffic and bikers. Waste of money.
column4: Dangerous for foot traffic and bikers. Waste of money.
column5: Do we really think this is a good idea/resourceful method to bring an economic impact to Atlanta? Rather than focusing on a 2 mile sidewalk, let's regroup our focus on transportation for all of Atlanta since we're projected to have an extra 5 million new transplants in the next 5 years. Or focus on our current drivers learning to actually drive better. It's in the city's best interest to focus on the safety of its citizens, rather than the constant gentrification, tacky ideas and construction sites, as well as trying to recreate this city's culture. I implore you to focus on my ideas, as I've been in the 30307 zip code for 10 years. Rather than making a profit, I care about this city, inside and out. Atlanta deserves more than a 3 mph streetcar that will already affect the traffic that this city has caused.

Marta’s reputation for providing a safe ride is horrible, and I am very concerned about these plans which are very rushed.
There are no current homeowners in the area who are excited about a streetcar stop in their backyard!
Are there any meetings currently scheduled to appeal these plans, and provide current resident’s opinions whose lives will be most impacted??
column6: I do not support the streetcar expansion. It will be a disaster and complete nuisance!!

column3: An additional station closer to the Krog street tunnel would be far more optimal to better connect neighborhoods that already feel disconnected south of Hulsey yard. The edgewood stop should be moved east of Howell street near Randolph, closer to the BeltLine, Krog tunnel, etc.. These plans seem to reinforce the idea that the the east side trail ends at the Krog St. tunnel. The current station position is awkward if approaching from the south and requires too much navigation. Given the unlikelihood of the street car to extend through Krog st tunnel anytime in the near future, providing easy of access for the rapidly growing Reyndoldstown and Cabbagetown neighborhoods should be considered.

column2: We can't see this happening in Atlanta, but if we could create a pedestrian-only zone including all these sections and create a zone similar to those in European cities, we'd be thrilled.
column3: We love the suggested solution of getting from Edgewood to the Beltline here.  It's going to a tough turn there by the tower, but there doesn't seem to be a great alternative.  Obviously if that section of Irwin were permanently closed off from traffic it would be great, but it's a tall order.
column4: Preference would be to have a hardscape protected bike lane and would give us more confidence to bike further from home than we do currently, so whichever plan eliminates parking or shared area with moving motorized vehicles, the better.
column5: As we mentioned in the comments earlier, we support extending the streetcar network as much as possible.  While we're huge proponents of public transit, we rarely take it currently, as we're lucky enough to be within walking distance of most of the places that enrich our lives.  We do however see ourselves using this streetcar extension a lot once constructed.  We love to walk and only drive when we have to.  To have easier access to the other neighborhoods we love within the city and to be able to go all the way downtown without worrying about parking and walking long distances in the heat would be a huge add to our lives.  All of that is just on the personal level, obviously.  We're excited for this project to make our city more connected and lively for everyone and this would be a huge help in doing so.

It is difficult for both pedestrians to cross Irwin, cars to cross the beltline, and pedestrians and bikers to get on the beltline from Irwin. column11: I live on this section of Auburn. This is terrible. We need street parking and also need to easily get down the street to get to our driveway. Turning onto airline is already dangerous. If that is not possible, could there be some sort of technology that allows the tram to send messages to the stop lights, informing them that it is arriving, and in turn, the stop lights will turn green for the tram? 

What will be the minimum and highest speed that the tram can go in these areas?

column2: Entire streetcar route
column5:
I support the position of BektLine Rail Now : Accelerate the Build Timeline

MARTA says it will take SIX more years to design and build a little more than two miles of light rail. Other experts say it can be done in as few as three years. We concur and urge you to ask for a shorter construction timeline. 2027 is too late!

Fix the Existing Streetcar

Reduce transit times by getting the streetcar out of traffic.

Support lane closures to vehicles both on the original route and the extension where practical.

Increased frequency of service (every 10 minutes instead of every 15).

Install a new station at the corner of Luckie Street and Forsyth Street to connect Peachtree Center MARTA to eastbound riders.

Give the streetcar the right of way by installing priority signaling across the entire route (both existing and new).

Build a Better BeltLine Rail

Move stops are closer to cross-streets (like Highland and Ralph McGill) so that it is easier for pedestrians and cyclists to connect.

Improve connectivity for cyclists and pedestrians at stations by installing amenities like secure bicycle lockers and Beltline-branded shelters and benches.

Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less storm water runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every Beltline rendering ever created
column6: At intersections with other transit (Marta trains and high volume bus routes)

column5:
Build better beltline rail:
Move stops are closer to cross-streets (like Highland and Ralph McGill) so that it is easier for pedestrians and cyclists to connect.

Improve connectivity for cyclists and pedestrians at stations by installing amenities like secure bicycle lockers and Beltline-branded shelters and benches.

Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less storm water runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every Beltline rendering ever created

Fix the Existing Streetcar: 
Reduce transit times by getting the streetcar out of traffic.

Support lane closures to vehicles both on the original route and the extension where practical.

Increased frequency of service (every 10 minutes instead of every 15).

Install a new station at the corner of Luckie Street and Forsyth Street to connect Peachtree Center MARTA to eastbound riders.

Give the streetcar the right of way by installing priority signaling across the entire route (both existing and new).

column1: ['Impact to pedestrian/cyclist experience on the BeltLine trail']
column5:
Thank you for creating this avenue to engage the community. 

I would strongly urge MARTA and the city of Atlanta to speed up the Streetcar E. Extension Project to 3-4 years (instead of 6+). While I don't live in this project area, I do ride my bike in it 3-6 times a week. 

Furthermore, it's important to get this segment complete so that we can extend north as well as south into my neighborhood (Reynoldstown). As you may know, there is a crush of new development along the Beltline and Memorial that is putting stress on our community's narrower streets. Light rail transit will be key in mitigating the need for cars while creating a safer and transit-rich community that offers real transit choice.

I look forward to seeing this become reality. Let's move this forward faster and more efficiently!

Thank you.

column1: ['Loss of trees/tree canopy']
column5:
Accelerate the Build Timeline!!!!

MARTA says it will take SIX more years to design and build a little more than two miles of light rail. Other experts say it can be done in as few as three years. We concur and urge you to ask for a shorter construction timeline. 2027 is too late!

Fix the Existing Streetcar

Reduce transit times by getting the streetcar out of traffic.

Support lane closures to vehicles both on the original route and the extension where practical.

Increased frequency of service (every 10 minutes instead of every 15).

Install a new station at the corner of Luckie Street and Forsyth Street to connect Peachtree Center MARTA to eastbound riders.

Give the streetcar the right of way by installing priority signaling across the entire route (both existing and new).

Build a Better BeltLine Rail

Move stops are closer to cross-streets (like Highland and Ralph McGill) so that it is easier for pedestrians and cyclists to connect.

Improve connectivity for cyclists and pedestrians at stations by installing amenities like secure bicycle lockers and Beltline-branded shelters and benches.

Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less storm water runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every Beltline rendering ever created

column3: This option needs more attention to bikes and other personal mobility devices. In general, bikes, wheelchairs, scooters and other personal mobility devices are key last-mile resources, helping integrate MARTA with all areas of the city/region. What is necessary is safe infrastructure, such as protected multi-use paths. Those facilities should make certain to prioritize vulnerable users by insulating them from car, truck, and bus traffic.

column4: I greatly oppose cycle tracks on primary roads - both for the safety of the cyclists and the negative impact on vehicular traffic. I would like to see CoA strive to create a network of bike trails on secondary roads (Cherokee instead of Boulevard) that will permit cyclists to get 90%+ of their way to and from their destinations without being in real vehicular danger. I would also strongly urge that those involve wait to impose road diets until AFTER mass transit solutions are in place.

column3: Let's talk agbout G and H since I live closets to there. The Auburn/Irwin intersection is already a great place to get T-boned, whether you're a car, cyclist, or pedestrian. As a pedestrian, it doesn't help that the sidewalk no longer exists on the water tower side of the street of Auburn Avenue. We've needed all-way stop signs at that intersection for ages but will need them even more with the streetcar there. We would also need all-way stop signs and perhaps a blinker of some kind at that five-way intersection at Auburn and Randolph, as that's also dangerous for everyone.

column21: I would support closing sections of Edgewood on the weekends. The foot traffic at the bars alone makes it difficult for cars to get through, and the cars that do show up are street racers who are exceptionally bad at their shenanigans. I'm less sure about partially closing that section of Irwin Street because it's already a moderate traffic car area, and the alternative for drivers going down Irwin Street is to detour around Krog and Edgewood, which sees fewer pedestrians and bicyclists but could create a traffic bottleneck.

The street car should be put somewhere else not next to the beltline where it could be a very high potential hazard for the mini pedestrians that the beltline encourages out daily.

column1: ['other']
column3: Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less stormwater runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every BeltLine rendering ever created.
column4: Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less stormwater runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every BeltLine rendering ever created.
column5:
It appears that MARTA has abandoned the BeltLine grass railbed, in favor of gravel for the BeltLine portion of the extension. Instead of a lush meadow that cradles a transit, are we getting an unwelcoming surface, hostile to pedestrians - especially those with disabilities? I hope not.

We must preserve this essential, green, and unique BeltLine design detail.

A few additional comments:
1 Accelerate the build timeline. Experts say it can be done in as few as three years. Why must we wait until 2027? It is just too late!

2. Fix the Existing Streetcar. Reduce transit times by getting the streetcar out of vehicular traffic. Let's close lanes to vehicles both on the original route and the extension where practical.

3. Increased frequency of service (every 10 minutes instead of every 15). 

4. Add a new station at the corner of Luckie and Forsyth Streets to connect Peachtree Center MARTA to eastbound riders.

5. Give the streetcar the right of way by installing priority signaling across the entire route (both existing and new).

5. Build a Better BeltLine Rail. Move stops closer to cross-streets (like Highland and Ralph McGill) so that it is easier for pedestrians and cyclists to connect.

6. Improve connectivity for cyclists and pedestrians at stations by installing amenities like secure bicycle lockers and Beltline-branded shelters and benches.

7. Preserve the green railbed or guideway wherever possible, promoting far less stormwater runoff, superior air quality, and the beautiful greenway envisioned in every BeltLine rendering ever created.

column1: ['other']
column3: The alignment of the tracks down Auburn Avenue is unacceptable and doomed to fail. The turns from Edgewood to Randolph to Auburn to Irwin the Beltline will be logistically challenging, a physics headache, and a nightmare for the impacted single family zoning districts along the proposed route. The street car should have connected onto the Beltline at/between Edgewood and Dekalb Avenue. The currently proposed route and stops for the streetcar are completely missing all of the new development that has occurred and is underway at Edgewood and the Beltline. The streetcar should either connect to the Inman Park Marta station down Edgewood, terminate at Edgewood and the Beltline until a new Marta station is added at Hulsey Yards and it's possible to reconfigure the Beltline for extension south of Dekalb Ave, or should be rerouted down Dekalb Avenue to the Beltline or Jackson and Irwin Street to the Beltline. The Beltline is drastically different now than when it was first envisioned, when the Streetcar was first envisioned, or even since either have been implemented in the last few years. I'm not convinced that the Streetcar is the correct mode of transit to be used on the Beltline in 2021 and beyond. We desperately need more transit along the Beltline and other high growth/high density areas, but we should be considering better alternatives to the streetcar. We should be considering a mode with a lighter infrastructure footprint and impact to the beltline and it's residents. We should be considering what other cities are using like automated bus rapid transit, which will allow for smaller cars and shorter headways.

column19: The alignment of the tracks down Auburn Avenue is unacceptable and doomed to fail. The turns from Edgewood to Randolph to Auburn to Irwin the Beltline will be logistically challenging, a physics headache, and a nightmare for the impacted single family zoning districts along the proposed route. The street car should have connected onto the Beltline at/between Edgewood and Dekalb Avenue. The currently proposed route and stops for the streetcar are completely missing all of the new development that has occurred and is underway at Edgewood and the Beltline. The streetcar should either connect to the Inman Park Marta station down Edgewood, terminate at Edgewood and the Beltline until a new Marta station is added at Hulsey Yards and it's possible to reconfigure the Beltline for extension south of Dekalb Ave, or should be rerouted down Dekalb Avenue to the Beltline or Jackson and Irwin Street to the Beltline. The Beltline is drastically different now than when it was first envisioned, when the Streetcar was first envisioned, or even since either have been implemented in the last few years. I'm not convinced that the Streetcar is the correct mode of transit to be used on the Beltline in 2021 and beyond. We desperately need more transit along the Beltline and other high growth/high density areas, but we should be considering better alternatives to the streetcar. We should be considering a mode with a lighter infrastructure footprint and impact to the beltline and it's residents. We should be considering what other cities are using like automated bus rapid transit, which will allow for smaller cars and shorter headways.

column5:
From visiting successful light rail cities ( Charlotte, Denver, Portland), Atlanta's Streetcar Design and Build along Auburn Ave does not have the look, feel and design of a fast forward progressive city, but an Older Canadian City trying to keep up with modern changes and failing to do so.  Let it stay in place as a tourist streetcar destination and possibly run up Peachtree Street in the future...thats where it belongs.  

The Beltline Light Rail should be designed and built by the forward thought provoking neighborhood blending light rail that gets us where we need to go and safely blends with the neighborhood without barricades, concrete walls, etc.  Simple, modern, quick, process management forward, upgradability for future modernization, minimal overhead power grid, etc

column4: Please meet with the owners of Thumbs Up about the cycle lane choices. Both their customers and Uber Eats drivers need quick access at their building, so their choice should weigh heavily in the plan. Same goes for the 3 new restaurants next to StapleHouse and Slutty Vegan Burgers.
column5:
I have owned my condo at the corner of Edgewood and Randolph for 16 years, and this also is planned to still be my home after I retire in 12 years. I cannot express strongly enough how much my neighbors and I are upset over this plan to run the streetcar just feet from our place of comfort and peace.
The current large-format streetcar vehicle with old-fashioned overhead wires would be such a detriment to the quality of life on our small residential streets. The wires are a junky, visual blight that don't portray the transit as being modern. Since so few people ride it after being around for years, changing it to a smaller, eco-battery powered vehicle would be sufficient.
Another detriment to our peaceful residential area will be the constant, annoying "ding-ding" bell. I work near the Ferris wheel now, and the bell sound is enough to make anyone crazy; at least I don't have to listen to it at home (yet). I want to discuss options for reducing or eliminating the bell sound in our residential area. Safety is all good and fine until residents start moving away because of the ruined quality of life.
 
Many of my neighbors on Randolph would like to know why DeKalb Ave. isn't being considered, where there are fewer residences to be disturbed. It's the logical place for the streetcar to get onto the Beltline and would allow it to travel through the immensely popular entertainment/shopping district on the Beltline at Edgewood. Or let it run straight east on Irwin from Jackson to the Beltline; a lot fewer homeowners would be impacted and teachers could use it.
I will write to Bryan Hobbs to request a Zoom call with all the homeowners that would be impacted along the proposed path. By my count, it would be about 73 standalone and condo homes on Edgewood, Randolph and Auburn.
Thank you.
column6: Please keep the stops away from the front doors of homeowners; very detrimental to our quality of life for numerous reasons.
